job_title: Adjunct Faculty in New Orleans, LA
pros: The university is very professional and provides amazing opportunities for staff and students.
cons: There are no cons for this employer.

job_title: Fund Development in New Orleans, LA
pros: You get to help advance the university's mission.
cons: Pay should be increased for the work done.

review_title: Low Pay & Place is too Convoluted
pros:
Many of the employees are very nice.
Cafeteria has amazing food.
cons:
1. Pay is way too low for worker bees who bear the brunt. Benefits could be better, especially vacation time. Don't have employees pay for parking, many do not make good wages to begin with.
2. Stuck in old ways of doing things,not conducive to change and not flexible.
3. Everything seems to convoluted and they make everything so complex that is gets tiring after awhile even for simple things. 
4, Too many VP's, AVP's and Directors/Managers that do not seem so necessary and slows everything little thing down. More working staff needed to get things accomplished. A problem in many non-profits, especially higher education.
5. Work/life balance is not very good. They expect too much of your time, like working 8 hours a day is not enough.

pros: Resilient, caring, supportive, sought-after by partner
cons: Limited budgetary resources as most HBCUs and privates face

pros: Students are respectful and colleagues are curtious.

Assistant Professor in New Orleans, LA

pros: Administration, colleagues, and support staff are top notch. Everyone is very supportive of your professional growth.
cons: The salary for non-tenured faculty members is relatively low.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros: Laidback environment, great employees, easy job
cons: I was never onboarded properly by my supervisor, who has held various positions around campus for over 20 years. His programs continue to lose funding, however he just continues to be placed in new departments to ruin them. Rather than explain to me the expectations of my new position, he left it up to my coworkers. He does not know anything that is actually happening in our department, instead he referrs me to my peers for answers to my questions because he does not make it a point to know anything. The school's president seems to be preoccupied with celebrity culture to the detriment of the school's actual problems. The building that my office is located in has leaks in the roofs. The tiles in my office were molded and covered with water marks when I first arrived. One tile was replaced and within weeks, it also had water marks on it. Many in our building have suffered from breathing ailments such as bronchitis which we believe is a result of our working conditions. The AC frequently goes out in the summer and the heat frequently goes out in the winter.

review_title: Opportunities for those with Vision and Perserverence
job_title: Middle Management in New Orleans, LA
pros: You get to be involved in a lot of different projects including those that affect student, staff, faculty experiences.  You can have a vision and you can work to make it come to fruition.   Your work journey at Dillard will allow you to travel in many different "lanes" due to the small size of the institution.  You will wear multiple "hats."
cons: Achieving program vision takes funding.  At Dillard, you may have to be creative, seek grants, or find workarounds.   Wearing multiple "hats" and having multiple responsibilities can be draining and can also hinder potential institution-changing and transformative successes.

pros: Good people and a great opportunity to become a change maker while helping educate a wonderful group of students who are often first generation college goers.
cons: Old school mentality; afraid of change; stuck in the "That's how we've always done it" mindset; students are sometimes not equipped for college.

review_title: Dillard University good place to work
job_title: Mid Level Administrator in New Orleans, LA
pros: Small; hands on culture; new ideas are supported
cons: Small; little to no access to funds allocated for your own program; new ideas are not funded (they like new ideas but expect you to find grant $ to fund and maintain them);

review_title: Great small private University situated in the heart of New Orleans, Louisiana
job_title: Technical Support in New Orleans, LA
pros:
Good family atmosphere.
Clear strategic staff vision and shared institutional advancement plan.
Good platform for getting into higher ed administration, education and non-profit.
All Government Holidays observed. 2-3 week paid winter break.
cons:
Pay was not competitive.
Not many opportunities for advancement
High Turnover w/ University President
